header_summary: Concerns regarding timing correlation and metadata intersection in transactions are addressed by random padding. ZmnSCPxj proposes a `keysend` protocol for multipath payments by embedding the preimage as TLV 5482373484. Tony and Bastien discuss deanonymizing techniques on the Lightning Network, with Tony emphasizing Acinq's awareness of sender and destination information. Carla announces the availability of recorded and transcribed specification meetings, accessible at [https://btctranscripts.com/lightning-specification](https://btctranscripts.com/lightning-specification).

recent_posts.title: BIP for Serverless Payjoin
recent_posts.summary:
- A concern has been raised about timing correlation and metadata intersection in transactions.
- The sender has knowledge of the transaction timing within a 10-second window and message size.
- Random padding of the Payjoin PSBT message size is recommended to address this issue.

recent_posts.title: Multipath Keysend
recent_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj proposed a `keysend` protocol for multipath payments on Lightning-dev mailing list.
- The receiver can only claim the payment after all parts of the payment arrive.
- ZmnSCPxj suggests embedding the preimage as TLV 5482373484 with a length of 32 in the `keysend`.

recent_posts.title: Blinded Paths Doom Scenario
recent_posts.summary:
- Tony and Bastien discuss deanonymizing techniques on the Lightning Network, focusing on recipient deanonymization.
- Tony raises concerns about a major LSP with direct routes and Acinq's awareness of sender/destination information.
- Bastien explains that mobile wallets and blinded paths can help preserve privacy in certain scenarios.

active_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
active_posts.summary:
- The context discusses the implementation of 2-of-2 Schnorr Musig2 for statechains.
- Blinded statechains rely on the server to report the number of partial signatures.
- Party 1 in the protocol does not learn certain information during the signing process.

active_posts.title: Ark: An Alternative Privacy-preserving Second Layer Solution
active_posts.summary:
- A new second-layer protocol called Ark has been released as an alternative to Lightning.
- Ark allows users to send and receive funds without liquidity constraints and consumes less on-chain footprint.
- It uses virtual UTXOs that must be spent within four weeks and can interoperate with Lightning.

active_posts.title: BIP-352 Silent Payments addresses should have an expiration time
active_posts.summary:
- Wallets can be compromised or lost, leading to addresses becoming toxic data.
- Silent Payment addresses allow multiple payments, but must eventually expire to avoid mistakes.
- Adding a 3-byte field encodes expiration date, with options for long periods of time.

active_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
active_posts.summary:
- LNbits team discovered an exploit allowing attackers to create balances through invoice manipulation.
- The exploit has been patched in LNbits version 0.10.5, urging users to update.
- Developers should implement additional checks and refer to the "payment hash" as the "preimage hash".

active_posts.title: Jamming Mitigation Dry Run
active_posts.summary:
- We are moving forward with the discussed plan to conduct a "dry run" of HTLC endorsement and local reputation tracking to gather real-world data and validate algorithms.
- The plan includes collecting anonymized forwarding data, propagating an experimental endorsement TLV, and implementing local reputation algorithms.
- Multiple teams will be involved in different aspects of the research, ensuring sensitivity and privacy concerns are addressed.
